questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient has hypertension and hypokalemia. His blood pressure is consistently elevated despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. Laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma aldosterone concentration and suppressed plasma renin activity. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an adrenal adenoma. Which is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spironolactone

 

Explanation :

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) is characterised by excessive production of aldosterone from the adrenal glands, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia.
  • Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist and a potassium-sparing diuretic, is the most appropriate drug of choice.

Spironolactone:

  • Aldosterone combines with an intracellular mineralocorticoid (MR) receptor and induces the formation of aldosterone-induced proteins (AIPs), which promote Na+ reabsorption.
  • Spironolactone acts as a competitive antagonist and inhibits the formation of AIP by combining with MR.
  • This prevents aldosterone from promoting sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, which are the primary mechanisms by which aldosterone increases blood pressure and causes hypokalemia.

Lisinopril (Option A) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that reduces aldosterone levels by inhibiting the production of angiotensin II.

  • However, in primary hyperaldosteronism, there is an autonomous overproduction of aldosterone.
  • Thus, lisinopril will be ineffective.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option B) is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits the reabsorption of sodium and potassium, thus hyperaldosteronism induced hypokalemia will be worsened.

Amlodipine (Option C) is a calcium channel blocker that works by relaxing the smooth muscle.

  • While effective for managing hypertension, it does not influence aldosterone levels or activity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Indomethacin

 

Explanation :

Indomethacin, a prostaglandin synthase inhibitor, is used for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, especially lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. It works by attenuating prostaglandin synthesis in the renal tubules, thereby potentiating the effects of antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

Oral carbamazepine (Option A) has shown antidiuretic activity in patients with neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus. It is suggested for initial use in neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus if oral therapy is indicated, although its exact mechanism of antidiuretic action is unclear.

Antidiuretic peptides (Option B)are the primary treatment for central DI, with desmopressin being the peptide of choice.

Chlorpropamide (Option C), an oral sulfonylurea, potentiates the action of small or residual amounts of circulating vasopressin and reduces urine volume in more than half of all patients with central DI. If polyuria is not controlled satisfactorily with chlorpropamide alone, adding a thiazide diuretic to the regimen usually results in an adequate reduction in urine volume.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents with symptoms of lethargy, nausea, and muscle cramps. laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia and plasma hypoosmolality. He has a history of lung cancer and was recently started on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for depression. He is diagnosed with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). Which of the following statements regarding the management of SIADH is incorrect?

choices.text: Fluid restriction to less than 800ml/day is the first-line treatment for Mild to Moderate SIADH.
Severe SIADH is corrected with administration of 100 ml iv bolus of 3% NaCl
Targeted sodium correction should be >1mEq/L per hour in case of severe SIADH
Demeclocycline and lithium can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate SIADH.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C). Targeted sodium correction should be >1mEq/L per hour in case of severe SIADH

Explanation:

Sodium correction should not increase 0.5-1mEq/L per hour, as it can cause severe consequences such as osmotic demyelination syndrome, which can even lead to quadriplegia.

Severity of SIADH

Symptoms

Management

Mild

Asymptomatic, Mild lethargy, nausea

Fluid Restriction

Moderate

Pronounced Lethargy, Confusion, Cramps, Nausea and Vomiting

Fluid Restriction, Loop Diuretics, Vasopressin Antagonists(VAPTANS), Demeclocycline, Lithium

Severe

Severe symptoms (e.g., severe confusion, seizures, coma)

Hypertonic saline, fluid restriction, Vasopressin Antagonist

Fluid restriction is the mainstay of treatment for mild to moderate SIADH, which is to be kept below 800ml/day.(Option A)

In cases of severe SIADH,100ml i.v. bolus of 3% NaCl is used to correct hyponatremia.(Option B)

Demeclocycline (Tetracycline) and lithium(Option D) can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate SIADH but not routinely preferred due to nephrotoxicity and availability of better drugs such as loop diuretics and vasopressin antagonists.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement with respect to vasopressin inhibitors?

choices.text: Conivaptan is used only as an intravenous formulation for hospitalised patients of hypovolemic/euvolemic hyponatremia.
Tolvaptan is given a black box warning and is intended to be given under close monitoring of serum Na+
Osmotic demyelination syndrome is one of the serious adverse effects of the usage of vasopressin antagonists.
Tolvaptan is a non-selective V1/V2 antagonist, while conivaptan is a selective V2 antagonist

questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D) Tolvaptan is a non-selective V1/V2 antagonist, while conivaptan is a selective V2 antagonist

 

Explanation :


Tolvaptan is a selective V2 antagonist while conivaptan is non selective V1/V2 antagonist. Since ADH acts on V2 receptors which reabsorbs water, tolvaptan helps in improving volume overload status by blocking those receptors.

Conivaptan(Option A) is FDA-approved for the treatment of hospitalised patients diagnosed with hypervolemic/euvolemic hyponatremia. It is also used in cases of emergency treatment of SIADH. Tolvaptan and mozavaptan are oral vasopressin antagonists used for long term management of the same.

Tolvaptan(Option B) is given a Black box warning as it can cause serious consequences by rapidly correcting hyponatremia. It is also hepatotoxic, thus should be used for a maximum of 30 days and should not be used in patients with liver disease.

Osmotic demyelination syndrome(Option C)can occur with the usage of vasopressin antagonists due to the risk of rapid correction of hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a history of bed-wetting three to four times a week. The child has no significant medical history and physical examination is normal. Which of the following is an incorrect statement with respect to initial management for nocturnal enuresis in this child?

choices.text: The drug of choice for nocturnal enuresis is intranasal desmopressin, administered at bedtime.
Primary nocturnal enuresis is the most common type where the child has never developed bladder control.
Initial management, in this case, is reducing water intake in the evening and doing bladder exercises.
Allergic reactions similar to urticaria or anaphylaxis can occur due to desmopressin administration.

questions.solution:
Correct  Answer: A) The drug of choice for nocturnal enuresis is intranasal desmopressin, administered at bedtime.

 

Explanation :

The drug of choice for nocturnal enuresis is oral desmopressin administered at bedtime that too only if behavioral and training methods fail. Intranasal desmopressin is no longer recommended because of the risk of hyponatremia in children.

 

Nocturnal Enuresis is of 2 types- Primary and Secondary.

  • Primary nocturnal enuresis is 3-5/ week incidences of bedwetting in children aged more than 5 years, indicating the child has not developed bladder control. (Option B)
  • Secondary nocturnal enuresis is a bedwetting incident occurring after the child has been dry for a period of at least 6 months, indicating the child has developed bladder control before

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient, previously operated on for pituitary adenoma, was diagnosed with post-operative central diabetes insipidus. All of the following are true regarding the drug of choice for this patient, except?

choices.text: The drug acts on V1 Receptor located in renal tubules
The preferred route is intranasal, as the drug is metabolised by trypsin in the gut
Cerebral oedema can occur as a serious adverse effect of this drug
The drug is contraindicated in patients with acute renal failure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The drug acts on V1 Receptor located in renal tubules

 

Explanation:


Desmopressin, which is the drug of choice in central diabetes insipidus, acts on V2 receptors located in renal tubules, not on V1

Preferred route for Desmopressin (Option B)is nasal or intravenous, as oral route is less efficacious due to getting metabolized by trypsin in the gut. However, in patients of acute rhinitis, oral route can also be used.

Since desmopressin(Option C)helps in absorbing more water, rapid correction of hypernatremia might occur, leading to cerebral oedema

Desmopressin(Option D) is not used in patients of acute renal failure as rapid increase in extracellular water can cause volume overload due to reduced renal function. Also, it is to be used very cautiously in patients of angina, hypertension and heart failure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis presents with progressively worsening abdominal distention, decreased urine output, and swelling in his legs. On examination, his abdomen is tense and distended with caput medusa and ascites, and his chest shows spider angioma. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum creatinine levels. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Terlipressin

 

Explanation:

  • Terlipressin is a vasopressin analogue that acts as a V1 receptor agonist, leading to vasoconstriction of splanchnic vessels and reducing portal hypertension.
  • It is the drug of choice for treating hepatorenal syndrome, as it helps improve renal perfusion and function in patients with advanced liver disease.

Spironolactone (Option B) is a potassium-sparing diuretic commonly used in the management of cirrhotic ascites.

  • It can help manage fluid overload but not the renal dysfunction seen in hepatorenal syndrome.

Furosemide (Option C) is a loop diuretic used to treat fluid overload in patients with cirrhosis and ascites.

  • However, in hepatorenal syndrome, loop diuretics may worsen renal perfusion and should be avoided.

Lactulose (Option D) is a non-absorbable sugar used to treat hepatic encephalopathy by reducing ammonia levels in the colon.

  • While hepatic encephalopathy can occur in patients with advanced liver disease, it is not the primary concern in hepatorenal syndrome, which involves renal dysfunction secondary to portal hypertension.

Explanation:

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents following a severe head injury. On examination, the patient is unconscious with signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). A CT scan reveals significant cerebral oedema and brain mass effect. The patient is scheduled for an emergency neurosurgery. Which medication is most appropriate for reducing cerebral oedema before and after the surgery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osmotic diuretics

 

Explanation :


Osmotic diuretics(mannitol) elevate the extracellular fluid compartment osmolality and thereby shift water from the extravascular into the intravascular compartment. This mechanism allows this group of drugs to treat conditions that raise ICP and also in acute attacks of glaucoma.

Loop and Thiazide diuretics(Options A & B )on the contrary can lower blood pressure and can lead to electrolyte imbalances, which may further compromise cerebral perfusion and worsen neurological outcomes in patients with increased ICP.

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors(Option D) are not as potent as osmotic diuretics, which are more effective in rapidly reducing intracranial pressure. They have limited ability to penetrate the blood-brain barrier, which limits their efficacy in managing increased ICP.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female with chronic heart failure is being treated with a diuretic to manage her symptoms of fluid overload. Recently, she has started to experience hearing loss and ringing in her ears. On reviewing her medications, which class of diuretics is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Loop diuretics

Explanation:

This patient has chronic congestive heart failure. She has been treated with furosemide, which is a loop diuretic. Loop diuretics are known to cause ototoxicity, which can manifest as hearing loss and tinnitus.

The most ototoxic loop diuretic is ethacrynic acid

questions.text: A patient on long-term lithium therapy visits with complaints of frequent urination and increased thirst. He was diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) based on urine analysis and plasma ADH levels. He was prescribed a combination of amiloride and hydrochlorothiazide. What is the reason for the use of thiazide diuretics in nephrogenic DI?

choices.text: Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules
Thiazides directly increase the sensitivity of the kidneys to ADH.
Thiazides help to increase lithium excretion, reducing its nephrotoxic effects.
Thiazides decrease the risk of hypokalemia when used with amiloride.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules

 

Explanation:

  • Thiazide diuretics reduce polyuria in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by inducing mild hypovolemia.
     
  • This hypovolemia leads to increased sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules, thereby reducing water delivery to the distal nephron.
     
  • As a result, urine volume decreases despite the kidney's resistance to ADH.
     

Mechanism of Action in Nephrogenic DI:

Drug

Mechanism

Thiazide diuretics

Induce mild volume depletion → ↑ proximal tubular reabsorption of water → ↓ urine output

Amiloride

Blocks ENaC channels in collecting ducts → ↓ lithium uptake → renal protection

Lithium

Causes nephrogenic DI by damaging ADH-sensitive pathways in collecting ducts

 

Thiazides directly increase the sensitivity of the kidneys to ADH (Option B):
Incorrect because nephrogenic DI is due to ADH resistance, and thiazides do not improve ADH sensitivity.
 

Thiazides help to increase lithium excretion, reducing its nephrotoxic effects (Option C):
Incorrect; thiazides actually increase lithium levels by reducing its clearance, potentially worsening toxicity.
 

Thiazides decrease the risk of hypokalemia when used with amiloride (Option D):
Incorrect because while amiloride reduces potassium loss, this is not the main reason for thiazide use in DI.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to thiazides and loop diuretics?

choices.text: Thiazides are preferred over loop diuretics in hypertensive patients with low GFR.
Thiazides cause indirect vasodilatation by prostaglandin release, unlike loop diuretics
Thiazides are preferred over loop diuretics in patients with osteoporosis
Thiazides will not cause hypokalemia, unlike loop diuretics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thiazides are preferred over loop diuretics in patients with osteoporosis

 

Explanation:

Thiazide diuretics decrease urinary excretion of calcium ions and are hence preferred over loop diuretics (which increase calcium excretion) in potential hypocalcemic states like osteoporosis

Loop diuretics (Option A) are preferred in patients with low GFR (<30 ml/min/BSA).only thiazide which is effective in low GFR cases is metolazone.

 Thiazides(Option B) cause direct vasodilatation by opening Ca2+ activated K+ channels on vascular smooth muscles.

Both loop diuretics (Option D)and thiazides can cause hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic hypertensive who hasn't taken his medication in the past three days presents with an acute severe headache, blurry vision, palpitations, and diaphoresis. On examination, blood pressure is 240/140 mm Hg. Which of the following is the ideal drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Furosemide

Explanation :

A hypertensive emergency is defined as blood pressure more than 220/120 mm Hg. Furosemide is the drug of choice in hypertensive emergencies due to its rapid onset and potent diuretic effect, effectively reducing blood volume and controlling severe hypertension.

questions.text: A patient with chronic renal failure and resistant oedema was treated with a drug that alleviated the oedema. However, increasing doses were needed over time. Although the drug remained effective, the patient developed involuntary hand twitching and perioral numbness. Which class of drug was given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loop diuretics

Explanation :

Involuntary hand twitching, along with perioral numbness, is suggestive of tetany due to hypocalcemia. High ceiling diuretics (loop diuretics), which are preferred in treating oedema (including resistant oedema and for rapid fluid mobilisation), impair the absorption of calcium ions, thus causing tetany.

  • Loop diuretics like furosemide primarily inhibit the sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
  • This inhibition disrupts the reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and water, which normally generates a positive potential gradient in the tubule's lumen.
  • This gradient facilitates the reabsorption of calcium ions. However, when loop diuretics block this transporter, the potential gradient is disrupted, impairing calcium reabsorption and leading to increased urinary excretion, ultimately resulting in hypocalcemia.

Common Adverse Effects of loop diuretics (also seen with Thiazides, except for Calcium):

  • Hyponatremia → Hypotension
  • Hypokalemia → Muscle weakness increases the risk of digoxin toxicity
  • Hypocalcemia → Tetany (Thiazides usually increase calcium levels)
  • Hypomagnesemia → Pseudogout
  • Decrease in H+ ions → Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hyperuricemia → in high doses
  • Hyperglycemia and dyslipidemia
  • Ototoxicity

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors(Option B), such as acetazolamide, have a weak diuretic effect and are primarily used for conditions like glaucoma or altitude sickness, not for managing significant fluid overload in CHF or chronic renal failure.

Thiazide Diuretics(Option C) are less effective than loop diuretics for severe oedema, especially in patients with chronic renal failure. They are typically used for mild to moderate oedema and maintenance therapy, not for rapid fluid mobilisation.
Osmotic Diuretics(Option D), like mannitol, are used to reduce intracranial pressure or treat acute renal failure but are not suitable for the long-term management of chronic oedema.

questions.text: A 32-year-old mountain climber presents to the base camp complaining of severe headache, nausea, and fatigue after ascending rapidly to a high altitude. On examination, his respiratory rate is increased, and arterial blood gas analysis shows decreased partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). Given the Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS) suspicion, acetazolamide is administered to alleviate symptoms. Which of the following best describes acetazolamide's primary mechanism of action in treating AMS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts in the proximal tubule, promoting bicarbonate excretion, leading to metabolic acidosis.
     
  • At high altitudes, hypoxia triggers hyperventilation, causing respiratory alkalosis, which depresses respiratory drive.
     
  • The metabolic acidosis induced by acetazolamide compensates for this alkalosis and helps stimulate ventilation, improving oxygenation and reducing symptoms of Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS).
     

 

 

Mechanism and effects in AMS:
 

Parameter

Change

High altitude effect

↓ PaO₂ → ↑ ventilation → ↓ PaCO₂ → Respiratory alkalosis

Acetazolamide effect

Inhibits carbonic anhydrase → ↑ HCO₃⁻ excretion

Acid–base result

Metabolic acidosis

Clinical outcome

Stimulates respiration, ↓ AMS symptoms

 

Respiratory Alkalosis (Option B): Incorrect because this is the initial disturbance at high altitude due to hyperventilation—not the result of acetazolamide therapy.
 

Respiratory Acidosis (Option C): Incorrect because acetazolamide does not impair ventilation or gas exchange; it does not increase PaCO₂.
 

Metabolic Alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect because acetazolamide causes loss of bicarbonate, resulting in metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

questions.text: All of the following are preferred uses of acetazolamide, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pulmonary hypertension

Explanation:


Acetazolamide cannot be used to treat pulmonary hypertension. The drug acts by inhibiting both membrane-bound and cytoplasmic forms of carbonic anhydrase.This results in nearly complete elimination of NaHCO3 reabsorption in the proximal tubule

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who has been treated for glaucoma comes with complaints of muscle weakness, fatigue, and palpitations. Laboratory tests reveal significant hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which class of diuretics is most likely responsible for these symptoms, considering the maximum loss of potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

Explanation :

  • This patient complains of muscle weakness, fatigue and palpitations after being started on a diuretic.
  • These symptoms suggest hypokalemia, and his ABG shows metabolic acidosis, which suggests the use of a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, which is commonly used in glaucoma.

 

Diuretics causing maximum potassium loss:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors cause the most potassium loss, followed by thiazides (Option B), loop diuretics (Option A), and osmotic diuretics (Option C).metabolic alkalosis is seen with thiazides and loops

 

Diuretics causing maximum sodium loss:

  • Loop diuretics lead to the greatest sodium loss, followed by thiazides, osmotic diuretics, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, and potassium-sparing diuretics.
